p: Thereafter, Canada experienced a secondary influenza A wave due to H3N2 subtype viruses that peaked unusually late, in March 2019 [ 3]. Several influenza A(H3N2) genetic clades contributed, the majority (> 60%) overall belonging to clade 3C.2a1b in Canada, Europe and Asia, with a minority (one-third or less) belonging to clade 3C.3a ( Supplementary Figure S1) [ 3- 7]. Conversely, clade 3C.3a viruses comprised the majority (> 70%) of influenza A(H3N2) detections in the United States (US) ( Supplementary Figure S1) [ 7- 10]. Clade 3C.3a viruses, which first arose in 2013/14, bear two substitutions within the immuno-dominant antigenic site B of the haemagglutinin (HA) glycoprotein. Both substitutions affect major antigenic cluster transition positions: one is clade-defining, namely a phenylalanine (F) to serine (S) substitution at HA position 159 (F159S), and another more recently acquired in 2016/17 is considered an accessory substitution, namely F193S [ 5- 7, 11- 13].
